fields.descriptive_line: A cast bronze Japanese version of a late 18th century European short barrelled howitzer decorated with several lines of incised characters on the underside and raised kanji on the top, Japan (Suruga), dated 1832
fields.physical_description: A cast bronze Japanese version of a European short barreled or hanging howitzer equipped with trunnions and cascable. Decorated with several lines of incised characters on the underside and two raised kanji characters on the top. The foresight is made from two parallel incised lines across top edge of the muzzle.
fields.dimensions: Length: 46.5 cm overall, Length: 39 cm to base ring, Length: 35.5 cm to vent, Diameter: 15 cm Muzzle, Diameter: 14 cm Base ring, Diameter: 6.5 cm Calibre, Weight: 25 kg, Width: 24 cm Across trunnions
fields.marks:
several lines of incised characters  A lengthy inscription on the underside translated in the early 1900's refers to a date of manufacture 'in the autumn of Tempo' corresponding with 1832 AD. Two founders names are cited; Yoshida Tansuke and Nakashima Yasagoro
 raised kanji  '? and yama'
fields.bibliography:
Robinson, B W, <u>Arms & Armour of Old Japan</u>, London, HMSO, 1951
Pl.25, top left
fields.history_note:
The muzzle face has taken an oblique blow with some force at some time. This has driven in the mouldings around the muzzle. Rather than evidence of the piece having been dropped, the curvature on the impact point is suggestive of a glancing blow by a cannon ball, suggesting that the piece may have been damaged in action.

Historical significance: As a result of the pressure to find metals to supply the war effort during World War II, a large quantity of historical bronze sculptures, lanterns, bells and cannon were melted down by the authorities making this a rare survivor of Japanese bronze artillery.

This piece supports the documentary evidence that Japanese founders were using European  (albeit somewhat outmoded) models, primarily from Dutch sources, in an attempt to close the developmental gap in artillery design in the early 19th century.
fields.historical_context_note:
This is a Japanese copy of a form of artillery widely used in European armies from the mid 18th century until ca.1820. In the 1820's this type of howitzer was superceded by a longer barreled version much closer in overall appearance to a conventional cannon (See 1027E-1871 and 1027G-1871 based on a French pattern ca.1828). 

The howitzer was used to fire exploding shells at a high trajectory. It was capable both of indirect fire, or of being used to fire canister at close range directly at an enemy with devastating results. The 2.5 inch calibre is much smaller than that of the earliest British howitzer (a 4.4 inch first introduced as early as 1728 firing a shell 8.5 lbs in weight).
